title: UK broadband has suffered because BT hasn't spent enough, claims Sky
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 17, 2015, 23:36 BST - UK Markets closed UK broadband has suffered because BT hasn't spent enough, claims Sky By Christopher Williams | Telegraph – 35 minutes ago 850.50 -12.00 
Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) claims BT has cut spending on maintenance of the UK's network, causing 'unacceptable levels of faults and service problems' 
Sky has accused BT of damaging broadband customer service and reliability by failing to invest in the upkeep of the national network, in a major escalation in the row over whether Britain’s former state telecoms monopoly should be broken up. 
The pay-TV operator, which is the country’s second-largest broadband provider via wholesale access to the network, claimed BT had cut spending on maintenance, causing “unacceptable levels of faults and service problems that continue to impact consumers and businesses”. 
Sky and TalkTalk are urging Ofcom, the communications regulator, to recommend that BT be forced to spin off Openreach, the division that runs the physical infrastructure sells access at regulated prices. 
Writing in The Telegraph , Mai Fyfield, Sky’s chief strategy officer, said: “BT’s case for the status quo is built on unfounded or exaggerated claims about the benefits of vertical integration and the risks of separation. 
“Most frequent is the claim that only BT would have invested £2.5bn in the roll-out of fibre. 
“In practice, fibre roll-out has been funded in part by cutting spending on other critical parts of the network, with service quality and reliability suffering as a result.” 
In response, Sean Williams, BT’s group director of strategy, policy and portfolio said: “This is plain untrue, no investments have been diverted away from Openreach. BT Group (LSE: BT-A.L - news ) has played a vital role by investing £10.5bn of capital in to Openreach over the past 10 years.” 
Ms Fyfield also suggested that BT’s plans for further upgrades using a technology called G.fast were inadequate and a symptom of the financial links between Openreach and the rest of the company. Rather than run fibre-optic lines all the way into homes and businesses, BT plans to avoid expense by squeezing faster internet access from the existing copper wires. 
Joe Garner, the chief executive of Openreach, kicked off the debate in The Telegraph on Monday when he made the case for Openreach to remain part of BT. 
The latest intervention raises the stakes as Ofcom considers the future of Openreach as part of its once-a-decade review of the communications sector. The regulator has said it is “seriously considering” a split as the most radical of four options (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
